item.title: Pixelblaze Output Expander
item.description: GITHUB PROJECT: github.com/Pi4J/pi4j-jbang > PixelblazeOutputExpander.java One of the most “fancy” electronic components is definitely a LED strip. It’s really cool to control a long strip of lights with only a few lines of code… But, there is a problem. The timing of the signals is crucial to reliably control these strips. Both Python and Java on a Raspberry Pi can struggle with these timings as they are running on Linux, a non-real-time operating system.

item.title: Controlling a LED Matrix
item.description: GITHUB PROJECT: github.com/Pi4J/pi4j-jbang > PixelblazeOutputExpanderImageMatrix.java A LED strip doesn’t only exist as a single strip, the same system is also used in a LED matrix. In this example, we will control such a 8*32 LED matrix. Intro This example is based on the Pixelblaze Output Expander (PBOE) JBang example. Make sure to check out the PBOE example, so you fully understand how to set up and use JBang, and connect and control a LED strip via a PBOE.

item.title: Controlling a LED strip with a JavaFX UI
item.description: GITHUB PROJECT: github.com/Pi4J/pi4j-jbang > PixelblazeOutputExpanderJavaFX.java We already know how to control a LED strip, so let’s add a JavaFX User Interface the colors on each of the LEDs on the strip. Intro This example is based on the Pixelblaze Output Expander (PBOE) JBang example. Make sure to check out the PBOE example, so you fully understand how to set up and use JBang, and connect and control a LED strip via a PBOE.
